title: Weather Service Chief Lauds Forecasters Who Contradicted Trump
text:
WASHINGTON—The head of the National Weather Service offered a robust defense of forecasters who contradicted President Trump’s claim that Hurricane Dorian posed a threat to Alabama.

Director Louis Uccellini said Monday at a meeting of the National Weather Association that forecasters in Birmingham “did what any office would do,” as they pushed back against a surge of unfounded rumors.

“They did that with one thing in mind: public safety,” said Mr. Uccellini, stressing that the office didn’t know where the inaccurate information was coming from when they tried to shut it down. Mr. Uccellini then asked the Birmingham staffers to stand to rousing applause.

Mr. Uccellini’s comments came as the controversy over Mr. Trump’s Sept. 1 claim that Alabama would likely be in the path of the storm dragged into a second week. At the time, forecasters weren’t expecting the state to be directly affected, and the president was quickly accused of using outdated information. But Mr. Trump has aggressively defended the statement, including displaying a doctored map that added Alabama to the path of the storm.

Late last week, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which oversees the NWS, issued an unsigned statement criticizing the Birmingham forecasters.

The acting chief scientist for the NOAA took issue with his agency’s response in an email to its employees Sunday. The email from Craig McLean, first reported by the Washington Post, was viewed by The Wall Street Journal. In it, he said he is investigating whether the agency’s response to Mr. Trump’s tweets constituted a violation of NOAA policies and ethics.

“My understanding is that this intervention to contradict the forecaster was not based on science but on external factors including reputation and appearance, or simply put, political,” Mr. McLean wrote. He added: “If the public cannot trust our information, or we debase our forecaster’s warnings and products, that specific danger arises.”

Mr. McLean added that he is pursuing any “potential violations of our NOAA Administrative Order on Scientific Integrity.”

Responding to the email, NOAA spokesman Scott Mullen said in a statement that “NOAA’s policies on scientific integrity and communications are among the strongest in the federal government, and get high marks from third-party observers. The agency’s senior career leaders are free to express their opinions about matters of agency operations and science. The agency will not be providing further official comment, and will not speculate on internal reviews.”

Dan Sobien, the president of the National Weather Service Employees Organization, said he was concerned that the spat over the storm’s path was politicizing public-safety information.

“I think what is important, what is extremely important is that the American public can trust the forecast and warnings the National Weather Service is putting out,” he said. “We cannot allow politics to get in the way of weather forecast and warnings. It’s going to cost people’s lives.”

Write to Catherine Lucey at catherine.lucey@wsj.com
